content:
Where to start. Your server is not noname. Withhold the actual email address if you like, but without the actual details of your server settings we will be guessing.

Thunderbird 78 is no longer supported and it may be can no longer get mail from blue host. Without knowing what the setting to be used are I can only guess.

I did look at blue hosts web site and they offer this very dated discussion. https://www.bluehost.com/help/article/email-application-setup Nothing there gives me a clie as to why you would be doing the things manually, but I would guess that you are using SSL/TLS and do not have an appropriate certifiect for your mail server. But I am guessing because I can not check the SSL of the server, or the DNS configuration.

Perhaps you can, and report the results page links. https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/ and https://intodns.com/

Than we have the issue that many folk with issues also have antivirus products that mess with mail and usually make getting it difficult by using self signed SSL certificates that Thunderbird knows nothing about.

Failing that, you can log the connection https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Logging to find out exactly what error messages are being propagated, but not making it to the point you see them.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
For 50Gb I would use a dedicated zip program, Thunderbird export tools appear to tap out long before you get to something like that. That is a LOT of mail.

Microsoft offer the following instructions here

Locate the file or folder that you want to zip. Press and hold (or right-click) the file or folder, select (or point to) Send to, and then select Compressed (zipped) folder. A new zipped folder with the same name is created in the same location. To rename it, press and hold (or right-click) the folder, select Rename, and then type the new name.

This link contains information on how to locate your profile folder if you need it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profile-manager-create-and-remove-thunderbird-profiles
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Ohh, I would guess exactly the same issue hat has plagued antivirus users,especially Nortons, for around a decade. In the case of POP mail accounts the antivirus silently drops into a coma when it encounters a malformed email and you get the same one, or even half a dozen emails that the server offers before it gets to the one that makes the A/V and the connection die. Next time you get the same ones, because the connection just died without completing the download of emails for the account and the cycle repeats ad nauseam.

The advice is usually given to delete the oldest email in the spam folder, or if you delete your mail the oldest, because folks for some reason do not react well to being told their antivirus is dodgy. You can also disable the antivirus and just get the mail. Either works as well as the other.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Let's talk about what you hate and what can be done to change it. The reality is old versions are inherently less secure and Thunderbird profile per install makes going back quite difficult, it is not a simple or reliable process. Basically if you could not find the information for yourself on this forum, where it has been repeated over and over for the last 3 years of so, you probably lack the skills to successfully revert to an old version.

Going back without loosing data of some kind almost impossible, even for the most technical savvy folk it is a struggle The process is covered in my blog post of 2019, but I do not recommend it as a process because you do not like the new version. In that instance I was trying to recover lost profiles, which yours will be after you install the old version.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thunderbird opens files based on the media type that the attachment is encoded as.

The DWG file extension is utterly meaningless in de5termining the media type. I appear to be seeing more and more poorly conceived email appearing on this forum from mostly web properties that send malformed email by failing to correctly encode attachments.

So before we waste any time tring to work out what is wrong with Thunderbird handling, please open the message source (ctrl+U) and scroll down until you encounter the attachments description in the message body.

It will look something like the following which is a PDF attachment in an email in my inbox. 

Content-Type: application/pdf; name="Thunderbird_CommunityFeedbackSurvey_Executive Summary.pdf" Content-Disposition: attachment; filename*0="Thunderbird_CommunityFeedbackSurvey_Executive Summary.pdf" Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64

My understanding from the IANA web site is the correct media type for DWG files is image/vnd.dwg https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml

The 1996 discussion proposing the format and the accepting it is here https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/image/vnd.dwg

What I am finding is we have a generation of developers writing mail applications that really do not know the first ting about email other that what they experience in Microsoft Outlook. They tend to encode the attachments to email is a random binary file. This works for mail clients that ignore the internet standards for the interchange of file data using mime encoding (Microsoft products mostly) but it does not work at all in standards compliant products.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: For gmail accounts, the user is not authorized to set the password. Instead, Google does that. My general suggestion to people is to set up the account and never enter password to Thunderbird. Then, when Google prompts for the email password, it creates a token that is stored as the password. If you change it, Gmail will not log in.
creator: davidsk

content: It takes time, but if you start using the junk controls, the spam will eventually become less frequent. This URL may help: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages Also, if the spam is coming from the same places, you could set up filters to minimize it. Personally, I also use the mailwasher software. It's free if used for just one account and it works very well if run before starting thunderbird.
